# Models in Academic Disciplines

## Natural Sciences

* **Physics**: The Standard Model describes fundamental particles and forces; Newton's laws of motion model mechanical systems and predict object behavior under forces. [Standard Model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Model) | [Newton's Laws](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newton%27s_laws_of_motion)

* **Chemistry**: The Bohr model represents atomic structure with electrons in defined orbits; molecular orbital theory models chemical bonding and molecular properties. [Bohr Model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bohr_model) | [Molecular Orbital Theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecular_orbital_theory)

* **Biology**: The Hardy-Weinberg model predicts allele frequencies in populations; the logistic growth model describes population dynamics with carrying capacity constraints. [Hardy-Weinberg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hardy%E2%80%93Weinberg_principle) | [Logistic Growth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_function#In_ecology:_modeling_population_growth)

* **Astronomy**: The Big Bang model explains cosmic origin and evolution; stellar evolution models predict how stars change over their lifetimes based on mass and composition. [Big Bang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Bang) | [Stellar Evolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stellar_evolution)

* **Geology**: Plate tectonics models explain continental drift and geological activity; the rock cycle model describes the formation and transformation of igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks. [Plate Tectonics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plate_tectonics) | [Rock Cycle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rock_cycle)

## Social Sciences

* **Economics**: Supply and demand models predict market equilibrium prices; the Solow growth model explains long-term economic growth through capital accumulation and technological progress. [Supply and Demand](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supply_and_demand) | [Solow Model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solow%E2%80%93Swan_model)

* **Psychology**: The cognitive-behavioral model links thoughts, emotions, and behaviors; Piaget's stages of development model children's cognitive growth through distinct phases. [Cognitive-Behavioral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_behavioral_therapy) | [Piaget's Theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Piaget%27s_theory_of_cognitive_development)

* **Sociology**: The structural-functional model views society as interconnected parts working toward stability; social network models map relationships and information flow between individuals. [Structural Functionalism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_functionalism) | [Social Network Analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis)

* **Political Science**: The median voter theorem models electoral outcomes in democratic systems; game theory models strategic interactions between political actors. [Median Voter Theorem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Median_voter_theorem) | [Game Theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory)

* **Anthropology**: Cultural evolution models explain how cultural traits spread and change; kinship models represent family relationships and social organization across cultures. [Cultural Evolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_evolution) | [Kinship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinship)

## Applied Sciences

* **Medicine**: The biopsychosocial model integrates biological, psychological, and social factors in health; epidemiological models (like SIR) predict disease spread through populations. [Biopsychosocial Model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biopsychosocial_model) | [SIR Model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compartmental_models_in_epidemiology)

* **Engineering**: Finite element models simulate stress and strain in structures; circuit models represent electrical systems using idealized components like resistors and capacitors. [Finite Element Method](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite_element_method) | [Circuit Theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrical_network)

* **Computer Science**: The OSI model describes network communication in seven layers; computational complexity models classify algorithms by their time and space requirements. [OSI Model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OSI_model) | [Computational Complexity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_complexity_theory)

* **Environmental Science**: Climate models simulate Earth's atmospheric and oceanic systems; ecosystem models track energy flow and nutrient cycling through trophic levels. [Climate Models](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_model) | [Ecosystem Model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_model)

## Humanities and Formal Sciences

* **Linguistics**: Chomsky's transformational-generative grammar models sentence structure and syntax; phonological models represent sound systems and pronunciation rules. [Transformational Grammar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transformational_grammar) | [Phonology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonology)

* **Mathematics**: Euclidean geometry models flat space using axioms and theorems; probability models describe random events and their likelihood. [Euclidean Geometry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euclidean_geometry) | [Probability Theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability_theory)

* **Philosophy**: The theory of forms models reality as imperfect reflections of perfect ideals; utilitarian models evaluate moral actions based on consequences and overall happiness. [Theory of Forms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_forms) | [Utilitarianism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Utilitarianism)

* **History**: Cyclical models view history as repeating patterns; the Annales school model examines long-term social and economic structures rather than just political events. [Cyclical Theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyclical_theory) | [Annales School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annales_school)

* **Education**: Bloom's taxonomy models learning objectives in hierarchical cognitive levels; constructivist models view learning as active knowledge construction by students. [Bloom's Taxonomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bloom%27s_taxonomy) | [Constructivism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constructivism_(philosophy_of_education))

* **Geography**: The von Thünen model predicts agricultural land use patterns around markets; gravity models estimate interaction between places based on size and distance. [Von Thünen Model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Von_Th%C3%BCnen_model) | [Gravity Model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravity_model_of_trade)
